cat: Customary units of measurement in the United States
wiki.text:
{|class="infobox" cellpadding="2" style="border: 1px solid darkgray;"
|+ '1 yard =' - colspan=2|'[[US customary units|US customary]]'/'[[Imperial
|  units]]' - 36 in || 3 ft - colspan=2|'[[SI units]]' - colspan=2| 0.9144 m }

, London - 1 yard (3 feet), 2 feet, 1 foot, 6 inches ( foot), and 3 inches. The
separation of the inside faces of the markers is exact at an ambient temperature
of 62°F (16°C) and a rod of the correct measure, resting on the pins, will fit
snugly between them.<ref>.</ref><ref></ref>]]

A 'yard' (abbreviation: 'yd') is a unit of length in several different systems
including United States customary units, Imperial units and the former English
units. It is equal to 3 feet or 36 inches. Under an agreement in 1959 between
Australia, Canada, New Zealand, South Africa, the United Kingdom and the United
States, the yard (known as the "international yard" in the United States) was
legally defined to be exactly 0.9144 metres.<ref name="Astin">A. V. Astin & H.
Arnold Karo, (1959), [http://www.ngs.noaa.gov/PUBS_LIB/FedRegister/FRdoc59-
5442.pdf Refinement of values for the yard and the pound], Washington DC:
National Bureau of Standards, republished on National Geodetic Survey web site
and the Federal Register (Doc. 59-5442, Filed, June 30, 1959, 8:45 a.m.)</ref>
Prior to that date, the legal definition of the yard when expressed in terms of
metric units varied slightly from country to country.
wiki.title: yard
